title: Chapter 3 Reactions
description: This arrangement is a series of lessons linked to the theme chemical reactions.

heading.content: Chapter 3 Reactions - paragraph 3.1 Conservation of mass and atoms

items.content:
The objective of this lesson is to recognize how the law of conservation of mass is related to balancing chemical equations.

Learning outcomes:

  1. You can define the law of conservation of mass.
  2. You can mathematically prove that mass is conserved in chemical reactions.
  3. You can use coefficients of reactants and products to balance the number of atoms of an element on both sides of a chemical equation.

French chemist Antoine Lavoisier carefully measured the mass of reactants and products in a combustion reaction. A combustion reaction is a chemical reaction in which something is burnt.

Lavoiser carried out his combustion experiment in a sealed jar, like in the picture below.

In every experiment he observed that the total mass of reactants (the substances before the reaction) was equal to the total mass of the products (the substances after the reaction). This showed that matter (atoms) cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction.

Antoine Lavoisier's law of conservation of mass was found to hold for all chemical reactions.

Another outcome of Lavoisier's combustion experiment was the discovery of oxygen.
Lavoisier carried out his reactions in a sealed glass jar. What might his experimental results have been if he used an open glass jar?

Let us take a closer look at an experiment between steel wool iron and oxygen in a closed environment. View the video below and answer the following questions:

Q1. What type of chemical reaction is demonstrated in the video?

Q2. Briefly describe the results of this experiment in your own words.

Q3. Does the experimental evidence support the law of conservation of mass?

Explain your answer.

items.caption: The combustion of iron in a closed environment.

items.content:
We learnt from the video that during a chemical reaction, e.g. the combustion of steel wool (iron) new molecules are formed with new combinations of atoms. There is the same number of atoms of each element before and after a chemical reaction. This explains the Law of Conservation of Mass: the mass of reactants and the mass of products are the same.

But, did you know that the Law of Conservation of Mass can also be proved mathematically?

header.title: Law of Conservation of Mass - mathematical proof

introduction.body: In the following questions, you will elaborate on your understanding of the mathematical evidence for the Law of Conservation of Mass.

prompt.body:
Nitrogen reacts with hydrogen to produce ammonia. The chemical equation for this reaction is written as follows:

N2 (g) + H2 (g) → NH3 (g).

Does this chemical equation obey the Law of Conservation of Mass? Use a calculation to support your answer.

values.value:
The total mass of the reactants = mass of N2 + mass of H2

The total mass of the reactants  = 2 x 14,0 u + 2 x 1,0 u = 30,0 u

The total mass of the reaction products = mass of NH3

The total mass of the reaction products  = 1 x 14,0 u + 3 x 1,0 u = 17,0 u

The total mass of the reactants is not the same as the total mass of the products.

Hence, this chemical equation does not obey the Law of Conservation of Mass.

content.body:
The total mass of the reactants = mass of N2 + mass of H2

The total mass of the reactants = 2 x 14,0 u + 2 x 1,0 u = 30,0 u

The total mass of the reaction products = mass of NH3

The total mass of the reaction products = 1 x 14,0 u + 3 x 1,0 u = 17,0 u

The total mass of the reactants is not the same as the total mass of the products.

Hence, this chemical equation does not obey the Law of Conservation of Mass.

prompt.body:
Iron oxide reacts with carbon monoxide to produce iron and carbon.

The chemical equation for this reaction is written as follows:

Fe2O3 (s) + 3 CO (g) → 2 Fe (s) + 3 CO2 (g).

Does this chemical equation obey the Law of Conservation of Mass? Use a calculation to support your answer.

values.value:
The total mass of the reactants = mass of iron oxide + mass of carbon monoxide

mass of Fe2O3 = 2 x Fe (55,8 u ) + 3 x O (16,0 u) = 159,6 u

mass of 3 CO   = 3 x CO (12,0 u + 16,0 u) = 3 x 28,0 u = 84 u

The total mass of the reactants = 159,6 u + 84 u = 243,60 u

The total mass of the reaction products = mass of iron + mass of carbon dioxide

The total mass of the reaction products = 2 x Fe (55,8) + 3 x CO2 (12,01 + 2 x 16)

The total mass of the reaction products = 2 x 55,8 + 3 x (44) = 243,60 u

The total mass of the reactants is the same as the mass of the reaction products.

Hence, this chemical equation does obey the Law of Conservation of Mass.

content.body:
The total mass of the reactants = mass of iron oxide + mass of carbon monoxide

mass of Fe2O3 = 2 x Fe (55,8 u ) + 3 x O (16,0 u) = 159,6 u

mass of 3 CO = 3 x CO (12,0 u + 16,0 u) = 3 x 28,0 u = 84 u

The total mass of the reactants = 159,6 u + 84 u = 243,60 u

The total mass of the reaction products = mass of iron + mass of carbon dioxide

The total mass of the reaction products = 2 x Fe (55,8) + 3 x CO2 (12,01 + 2 x 16)

The total mass of the reaction products = 2 x 55,8 + 3 x (44) = 243,60 u

The total mass of the reactants is the same as the mass of the reaction products.

Hence, this chemical equation does obey the Law of Conservation of Mass.

heading.content: Explore and Explain - Balancing Chemical Equations

items.content:
Every chemical reaction must have the same number of atoms on both sides of the equation to satisfy the Law of Conservation of Mass.

Listen to the audio explanations below to learn more about the rules and the best method to balancing chemical equations.

items.title: The rules of Balancing Chemical Equations
Step-by-step guide to Balancing Chemical Equations

introduction.body: In this diagnostic exercise, you'll complete the following chemical equations by adding the correct coefficients.

content.body: .2 Na + ....I<sub>2</sub> → ..2.NaI
This is the correct answer, because all atoms are  balanced.
This is an incorrect answer, because you didn't choose the smallest whole numbers as coefficients.
2 Ca + ...O<sub>2</sub> → 2 CaO
This is the correct answer, because all atoms are balanced.
2 Ca + .1.O<sub>2</sub> → 2 CaO
This is not correct, because you may never write '1' as a coefficient.

prompt.body: ....PbO2 + .....HCl → ....PbCl4 + .....H2O

content.body: 2.PbO<sub>2 </sub> + ..4..HCl → .2.PbCl<sub>4</sub> + ..2.H<sub>2</sub>O
This is incorrect, because the atoms aren't balanced.
...PbO<sub>2 </sub> + ...4..HCl → ....PbCl<sub>4</sub> + ...2.H<sub>2</sub>O
This is the correct answer, because all atoms are balanced.

prompt.body: .....C6H12O6 → ...C + ....H2O

content.body: .....C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> → 6.C + ..6.H<sub>2</sub>O
This is correct, because all atoms are balanced.
...2..C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> → .6..C + ..12..H<sub>2</sub>O
This is an incorrect answer, because the atoms aren't balanced.

items.content:
Balancing chemical equations exercises are fun to do when you get the hang of it.

But there's much more to balancing chemical equations than deciding which coefficients must be on the dotted line.

Listen to the audio explanations below and learn to write your own balanced chemical equations from words.

items.title: Writing Balanced Chemical Equations from words

header.title: Writing Balanced Chemical Equations from words

introduction.body: This diagnostic test will assess how good you are at writing balanced chemical equations from words.

prompt.body:
Magnesium reacts with carbon dioxide to yield carbon and magnesium oxide (MgO).

Write the balanced chemical equation for this reaction.

Use the following format:

Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: ................+............→.............+...............

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: .................(..) + ..............(...) →.............(...) +...............(...)

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: .................(...) + ..............(...) →.............(...) +...............(...)

values.value:
Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: Magnesium + Carbon dioxide → Carbon + Magnesium oxide              [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: Mg (s)   + CO2 (g) → C (s) +MgO (s)                                                     [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: 2 Mg (s)   + CO2 (g) → C (s) + 2 MgO (s)                                              [1p]

content.body:
Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: Magnesium + Carbon dioxide → Carbon + Magnesium oxide [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: Mg (s) + CO2 (g) → C (s) +MgO (s) [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: 2 Mg (s) + CO2 (g) → C (s) + 2 MgO (s) [1p]

prompt.body:
Flambé is a cooking method in which alcohol is added to a hot pan to create a burst of flames. Alcohol (C2H6O) reacts with oxygen to yield carbon dioxide and water.

Write the balanced chemical equation for this reaction.

Use the following format:

Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: ................+............→.............+...............

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: .................(..) + ..............(...) →.............(...) +...............(...)

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: .................(...) + ..............(...) →.............(...) +...............(...)

values.value:
Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words:

Step 1: Alcohol + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water                                [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol:

Step 2: C2H6O (l)   + O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l)                                          [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation:

Step 3:  C2H6O (l)   + 3 O2(g) → 2 CO2(g) + 3 H2O(l)                                [1p]

content.body:
Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words:

Step 1: Alcohol + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol:

Step 2: C2H6O (l) + O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation:

Step 3: C2H6O (l) + 3 O2(g) → 2 CO2(g) + 3 H2O(l) [1p]

heading.content: Evaluate - Lavoisier's law and Balancing Chemical Equations.

items.content: Complete the diagnostic test to track your own progress.

header.title: Diagnostic test Ch3 paragraph 3.1 Conservation of mass and atoms

prompt.body:
Barium reacts with magnesium carbonate to yield barium carbonate and magnesium.

Does this chemical reaction obey the Law of Conservation of Mass?

Use a calculation to support your answer.

values.value:
Law of Conservation mass: mass of the reactants = mass of the reaction products.

Total mass of the reactants = mass of Ba + mass of MgCO3  

Total mass of the reactants =   1 x 137,3 u + 1x 24,3 u + 1 x 12,0 u + 3 x 16,0 u [1p]

Total mass of the reactants  =   221,60 u

Total mass of the reaction products = mass of BaCO3 +  Mg

Total mass of the reaction products = 1x 137,3 + 1 x 12,0 + 3 x 16 + 1 x 24,3 [1p]

Total mass of the reaction products = 221,60 u  

Conclusion: Yes, this chemical reaction does obey the Law of Conservation of Mass because the mass of the reactants is equal to the mass of the products [1p].

content.body:
Law of Conservation mass: mass of the reactants = mass of the reaction products.

Total mass of the reactants = mass of Ba + mass of MgCO3

Total mass of the reactants = 1 x 137,3 u + 1x 24,3 u + 1 x 12,0 u + 3 x 16,0 u [1p]

Total mass of the reactants = 221,60 u

Total mass of the reaction products = mass of BaCO3 + Mg

Total mass of the reaction products = 1x 137,3 + 1 x 12,0 + 3 x 16 + 1 x 24,3 [1p]

Total mass of the reaction products = 221,60 u

Conclusion: Yes, this chemical reaction does obey the Law of Conservation of Mass because the mass of the reactants is equal to the mass of the products [1p].

prompt.body: According to the Law of Conservation of Mass, how much sodium sulfate was required for this chemical reaction? Show a calculation to support your answer.

values.value:
Total mass of reactants: mass of Na+mass of CaSO4= 23 g + 136,2 g= 159,2 g [1p]

Total mass of the reaction products = mass of Na(SO4)2 + mass of Ca

mass of Na(SO4)2=mass of the reactants - mass of Ca = 159,2 - 40,1= 119,1 g [1p]

Thus, according to the Law of Conservation of Mass,119,1 g of sodium sulphate was required for this chemical reaction.

content.body:
Total mass of reactants: mass of Na+mass of CaSO4= 23 g + 136,2 g= 159,2 g [1p]

Total mass of the reaction products = mass of Na(SO4)2 + mass of Ca

mass of Na(SO4)2=mass of the reactants - mass of Ca = 159,2 - 40,1= 119,1 g [1p]

Thus, according to the Law of Conservation of Mass,119,1 g of sodium sulphate was required for this chemical reaction.

prompt.body:
The reaction between, a solid named diphosphorus pentoxide (P2O5) and water yields a solution of phosphoric acid (H3PO4) . The state symbol for solid (s) and state symbol for solution is (aq).

Write the balanced chemical equation for this reaction.

Use the following format:

Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: ................+............→.............

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: .................(..) + ..............(...) →.............(...)

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: .................(...) + ..............(...) →.............(...)

values.value:
Write the balanced chemical equation for this reaction.

Use the following format:

Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: diphosphorus pentoxide + water → phosphoric acid   [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2:  P2O5 (s)   + H2O (l) →H3PO4 (aq)                              [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3:  P2O5 (s)   + 3 H2O (l) → 2 H3PO4 (aq)                       [1p]

content.body:
Write the balanced chemical equation for this reaction.

Use the following format:

Step 1: Write the chemical equation in words

Step 1: diphosphorus pentoxide + water → phosphoric acid [1p]

Step 2: Translate the chemical names into chemical formulas en state symbol.

Step 2: P2O5 (s) + H2O (l) →H3PO4 (aq) [1p]

Step 3: Give the balanced chemical equation

Step 3: P2O5 (s) + 3 H2O (l) → 2 H3PO4 (aq) [1p]

items.content:
The objective of this lesson is to distinguish between the two types of combustion.

Learning outcomes:

  1. You can describe which three conditions are required for combustion to occur.
  2. You can write balanced complete and incomplete combustion equations from words.
  3. You can discuss the environmental effects of both types of combustion.
You are deep frying chicken wings when some hot oil spills down the side of your pan and catches fire in the gas flame. What would you do to stop this chip pan fire?

items.caption: Putting out a chip pan fire

heading.content: Engage, Explore and Explain - Fire triangle

items.content: Combustion is the scientific term used for burning. Burning wood over a camp fire, burning carbs in your body and even skin injuries caused by heat are examples of combustion reactions.

prompt.body: Define a combustion reaction.

values.value: Combustion is a chemical reaction that requires fuel and oxygen to produce gaseous products and energy in the form of heat, light or sound.

content.body: Combustion is a chemical reaction that requires fuel and oxygen to produce gaseous products and energy in the form of heat, light or sound.

prompt.body: What are the reactants in a combustion reaction?

values.value: The reactants in a combustion reaction are fuel and oxygen.

content.body: The reactants in a combustion reaction are fuel and oxygen.

prompt.body: What are the products in a combustion reaction?

values.value: The products in a combustion reaction are gaseous products, such as carbon dioxide gas and water vapor, and heat.

content.body: The products in a combustion reaction are gaseous products, such as carbon dioxide gas and water vapor, and heat.

prompt.body: Explain the importance of combustion reactions in our life.

values.value: Combustion reactions are important for the way we live.                                           We use them to keep warm, to heat, to cook, to move cars/ships/planes, for manufacturing and to produce electricity.

content.body: Combustion reactions are important for the way we live. We use them to keep warm, to heat, to cook, to move cars/ships/planes, for manufacturing and to produce electricity.

items.content:
The fire triangle (or combustion triangle) shows the three conditions to start and sustain a fire.

Bush fires in Australia are caused by spontaneous combustion of dry fuel, such as saw dust or dry leaves. Fire fighters use their knowledge of the fire triangle to extinguish the fire by removing one or more of the tree conditions for fire to occur.

header.title: How would you extinguish the fire?

introduction.body: In this diagnostic test, you can assess whether you got the skills to be an effective fire fighter.

prompt.body:
A burning match or birthday candle can be extinguished by blowing on it, whereas a forest fire burns more rapidly when a strong wind blows on it.

Explain this difference.

values.value:
By blowing on the burning match or birthday candle you blow the combustion gases away from the fuel. [1p]

In a forest fire there is fuel everywhere; Wind increases the supply of oxygen, which makes the forest fire spread more rapidly. [1p]

content.body:
By blowing on the burning match or birthday candle you blow the combustion gases away from the fuel. [1p]

In a forest fire there is fuel everywhere; Wind increases the supply of oxygen, which makes the forest fire spread more rapidly. [1p]

prompt.body:
The extinguishing method of 'removing fuel' can be applied in various ways.

Explain how the fuel removal method can be carried out in bush fires.

values.value: A small area of bush is cleared; this is also used as a preventive measure .[1p]

content.body: A small area of bush is cleared; this is also used as a preventive measure .[1p]

prompt.body:
The extinguishing method of 'removing fuel' can be applied in various ways.

Explain how this method is applied when a leaking gas pipe has caught fire.

values.value: A burning gas pipe is extinguished by turning off the (main) gas supply. [1p]

content.body: A burning gas pipe is extinguished by turning off the (main) gas supply. [1p]

items.content:
Listen to the audio explanation below to learn more about :

  • the difference between complete and incomplete combustion.
  • how to write balanced combustion reactions from words.

prompt.body: Give the balanced chemical equation for the complete combustion of propane (C3H8).

values.value:
The skeleton (unbalanced) equation for the complete combustion of propane:

C3H8 + O2 → CO2 + H2O                                                             [1p]

The balanced equation for the complete combustion of propane:

C3H8 + 5 O2 → 3 CO2 + 4 H2O                                                    [1p]

content.body:
The skeleton (unbalanced) equation for the complete combustion of propane:

C3H8 + O2 → CO2 + H2O [1p]

The balanced equation for the complete combustion of propane:

C3H8 + 5 O2 → 3 CO2 + 4 H2O [1p]

prompt.body:
Give the balanced chemical equation for the complete combustion of

carbon disulfide, CS2

values.value:
The skeleton (unbalanced) equation for this reaction:

CS2   +  O2 → CO2 + SO2                                                     [1p]

The balanced equation for this reaction:

CS2   +  3 O2 → CO2 + 2 SO2                                               [2p]

Be aware, water is not produced in this reaction, because the fuel in this question does not consist of hydrogen atoms!

content.body:
The skeleton (unbalanced) equation for this reaction:

CS2 + O2 → CO2 + SO2 [1p]

The balanced equation for this reaction:

CS2 + 3 O2 → CO2 + 2 SO2 [2p]

Be aware, water is not produced in this reaction, because the fuel in this question does not consist of hydrogen atoms!

prompt.body:
Give the balanced chemical equation for the complete combustion of

magnesium sulphide, MgS

content.body: MgS + O<sub>2 </sub> --> MgO  + SO<sub>2</sub>
this is the skeleton equation, not the balanced one.
2 MgS + 3 O<sub>2</sub> --> 2 MgO + 2 SO<sub>2</sub>
this is balanced equation, because it has the correct coefficients in front of the reactants and reaction products
MgS + O<sub>2</sub> --> MgO  + SO<sub>2</sub> + CO<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O
None of our reactants contain Carbon or Hydrogen atoms. So, this reaction cannot produce carbon dioxide and water.

items.content: Complete the diagnostic test to track your own progress.

prompt.body:
Matthew blew out the Bunsen Burner before switching off the gas supply.

Explain which part of the fire triangle was removed.

values.value: The cool air coming from Matthew's breath pushes the hot air from the flame away from the gas coming out of the Bunsen burner, so the heat is removed from the flame.

content.body: The cool air coming from Matthew's breath pushes the hot air from the flame away from the gas coming out of the Bunsen burner, so the heat is removed from the flame.

prompt.body:
Why wouldn't you use water as an extinguishing method in an electrical fire?

Explain your answer.

values.value: Water is a natural conductor of electricity and if you throw water on an electrical fire, you can get shocked or electrocuted.

content.body: Water is a natural conductor of electricity and if you throw water on an electrical fire, you can get shocked or electrocuted.

prompt.body: Give the balanced chemical equations for the complete and incomplete combustion of Toluene, C6H5CH3.

values.value:
The balanced equation for the complete combustion of Toluene:

C6H5CH3 + 9 O2 → 7 CO2 + 4 H2O                                        [2p]

The balanced equation for the incomplete combustion of Toluene:

C6H5CH3 +  5 O2 → C + 6 CO + 4 H2O                                   [2p]

content.body:
The balanced equation for the complete combustion of Toluene:

C6H5CH3 + 9 O2 → 7 CO2 + 4 H2O [2p]

The balanced equation for the incomplete combustion of Toluene:

C6H5CH3 + 5 O2 → C + 6 CO + 4 H2O [2p]

prompt.body: Give the balanced equation for the complete and incomplete combustion of Acetone, C3H6O.

values.value:
The balanced equation for the complete combustion of acetone:

C3H6O + 4O2 → 3 CO2 + 3 H2O                                        [2p]

The balanced equation for the incomplete combustion of acetone:

C3H6O + 2 O2 → C + 2 CO + 3 H2O                                  [2p]

content.body:
The balanced equation for the complete combustion of acetone:

C3H6O + 4O2 → 3 CO2 + 3 H2O [2p]

The balanced equation for the incomplete combustion of acetone:

C3H6O + 2 O2 → C + 2 CO + 3 H2O [2p]

items.content:
The objective of this lesson is to understand that decomposition and combustion are two different chemical processes that differ in uptake or release of energy.

Learning outcomes:

1. You can explain that decomposition is a chemical reaction and not a separation method.

2. You can describe the difference between the three types of decomposition methods.

3. You can write a balanced decomposition reaction from words.

4. You can sketch the energy change in combustion and decomposition reactions.
What do you think decomposition is about? Is it a chemical reaction or separation method?

heading.content: Explore and Explain - Three Decomposition methods

items.content:
As stated earlier, decomposition is a chemical process of splitting a compound up into smaller molecules.

There are three ways to decompose a compound:

  • Thermal decomposition (or Thermolysis) uses heat to break down a compound.
  • Photodecomposition (or Photolysis) uses light to break down a compound.
  • Electrolysis uses an electric current to break down a compound.

items.caption: Electrolysis of water using Hoffman's apparatus

prompt.body: Give a definition of thermal decomposition.

content.body: The word thermal means electricity and another way of saying breaking down is 'decompose' - so thermal decomposition means to break down with electricity.
The word thermal means light and another way of saying breaking down is 'decompose' - so thermal decomposition means to break down with light.
The word thermal means heat and another way of saying breaking down is 'decompose' - so thermal decomposition means to break down with heat.

Fill in the gaps

Copper carbonate is a ,when heated it..and the gas was given off. We could demonstrate the presence of this gas because limewater changed from a to a

Copper carbonate is a compound, when heated it decomposed and the gas carbon dioxide was given off. We could demonstrate the presence of this gas because limewater changed from a colourless solution to a white suspension.

values.value: ionic compound
decomposed
carbon dioxide
colourless solution
white suspension

prompt.body:
The photodecomposition of silver nitrate played a key role in early black and white photography.

Silver chloride is easily formed as a precipitate by combining aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and hydrogen chloride.

Why would you always have to make fresh silver chloride solution when you need it?

values.value: Silver chloride is sensitive to light. When exposed to ultraviolet light, it decomposes to produce the element silver and chlorine gas.

content.body: Silver chloride is sensitive to light. When exposed to ultraviolet light, it decomposes to produce the element silver and chlorine gas.

prompt.body:
A Hoffman apparatus is used for electrolysing water. When current is run through the Hoffman apparatus, gaseous products are formed at the electrodes. The cathode type of electrode delivers electrons (negative charge) and the anode collects electrons (positive charge).

Which two observations led you to conclude that two different gases are formed in the electrolysis of water?

values.value:
Observation 1: the volume of the gas released at the cathode is double that of the gas formed at the anode. This means that hydrogen gas is produced at the cathode and oxygen gas is produced at the anode.

Observation 2: By holding a splint above the test tube:

  1. Put a lighted splint into a test tube of hydrogen. You will hear a squeaky pop.
  2. Put a glowing splint into a test tube of oxygen. The glowing splint will relight.

content.body:
Observation 1: the volume of the gas released at the cathode is double that of the gas formed at the anode. This means that hydrogen gas is produced at the cathode and oxygen gas is produced at the anode.

Observation 2: By holding a splint above the test tube:

  1. Put a lighted splint into a test tube of hydrogen. You will hear a squeaky pop.
  2. Put a glowing splint into a test tube of oxygen. The glowing splint will relight.

items.content:
Listen to the audio explanation to learn more about:

  • writing balanced chemical equations for decomposition reactions from words.
  • the difference between exothermic and endothermic reactions.

items.title: Writing Decomposition reactions + exothermic and endothermic reactions

introduction.body: This test will assess your knowledge on exothermic and endothermic processes.

prompt.body:
Ammonia decomposes into the nitrogen and hydrogen molecules.

Write down the balanced chemical equation for the decomposition of ammonia (NH3).

values.value:
Step 1:  ammonia → nitrogen + hydrogen                                       [1p]

Step 2:  NH3 (g)   → N2 (g) + H2 (g)                                                 [1p]

Step 3:  2NH3 (g) → N2 (g) + 3 H2 (g)                                              [1p]

content.body:
Step 1: ammonia → nitrogen + hydrogen [1p]

Step 2: NH3 (g) → N2 (g) + H2 (g) [1p]

Step 3: 2NH3 (g) → N2 (g) + 3 H2 (g) [1p]

prompt.body:
Sketch an energy graph for the decomposition of ammonia.

Your energy graph should include the key words: reactants, products, activation energy, reaction progress and energy.

items.content: Complete the diagnostic test to track your own progress.

prompt.body: Chalk (CaCO3) is strongly heated to produce calcium oxide (CaO) and carbon dioxide. Is this an endothermic or exothermic reaction? Explain your answer.

values.value: It is an endothermic reaction, because heat is needed for chalk to decompose into calcium oxide and carbon dioxide [1p].

content.body: It is an endothermic reaction, because heat is needed for chalk to decompose into calcium oxide and carbon dioxide [1p].

prompt.body:
RDX was a common military explosive that was widely used during World War II.

The chemical formula of RDX is C3H6N6O6.

RDX decomposes into carbon monoxide, water and nitrogen.

Give the balanced chemical equation of this decomposition reaction.

values.value:
step 1:   RDX →  carbon monoxide + water + nitrogen  [1p]

step 2:    C3H6N6O6 → CO + H2O + N2                                   [1p]

step 3:    C3H6N6O6 → 3 CO + 3 H2O + 3 N2                 [1p]

content.body:
step 1: RDX → carbon monoxide + water + nitrogen [1p]

step 2: C3H6N6O6 → CO + H2O + N2 [1p]

step 3: C3H6N6O6 → 3 CO + 3 H2O + 3 N2 [1p]

prompt.body:
Invented in 1847, nitroglycerine has been used as dynamite in the construction, demolition and mining industries. Nitroglycerine is so unstable that the slightest friction can cause it to spontaneously detonate. The detonation reaction of nitroglycerine is written below:

4 C3H5N3O9 → 6 N2 + 12 CO2 + 10 H2O + O2

Is the detonation of nitroglycerine a decomposition and/or a combustion reaction? Explain your answer.

values.value: This is a decomposition reaction because there nitroglycerine is broken down to smaller molecules [1p]. This reaction is also a combustion reaction because CO2 and H2O are formed as combustion products and there are flames [1p]. (This is also called ‘internal combustion’ because the oxygen comes from the fuel.)

content.body: This is a decomposition reaction because there nitroglycerine is broken down to smaller molecules [1p]. This reaction is also a combustion reaction because CO2 and H2O are formed as combustion products and there are flames [1p]. (This is also called 'internal combustion' because the oxygen comes from the fuel.)

prompt.body:
While an athlete's body performs strenuous exercise, glucose (C6H12O6) is decomposed to lactic acid (C3H6O3). This reaction is not beneficial for athletes.

Why are athetes not helped by this reaction?

values.value: The formation of excess lactic acid in muscles is generally knowns as the ‘acidification’ of muscles (or cramp). It is painful, because the athlete is no longer able to perform [1p]

content.body: The formation of excess lactic acid in muscles is generally knowns as the 'acidification' of muscles (or cramp). It is painful, because the athlete is no longer able to perform [1p]

prompt.body:
Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a familiar bleaching agent. Hydrogen peroxide slowly decomposes under exposure to light into water oxygen. For safety reasons, it is stored in weakly acidic solution in a dark colored bottle.

Why is hydrogen peroxide solution not stored in an ordinary colourless bottle? Explain your answer.

values.value: Hydrogen peroxide is kept in a dark bottle so that no light enters the bottle. This is because exposure to light causes decomposition of hydrogen peroxide [1p]

content.body: Hydrogen peroxide is kept in a dark bottle so that no light enters the bottle. This is because exposure to light causes decomposition of hydrogen peroxide [1p]

items.content:
The objective of this lesson is to explain differences in reaction rates with the particle collision model.

Learning outcomes:

  1. You can define the rate of reaction.
  2. You can describe 5 factors that affect the rate of reaction.
  3. You can use the particle collision model to explain which factor is more likely to accelerate a reaction in different situations.

The speed at which substances react together is called the rate of reaction.

Reactions between alkali metals and water are very fast, but the chemical weathering of rocks is very slow.

heading.content: Explore and Explain - factors affecting the reaction rate

items.content:
The rate of reaction is affected by 5 factors:

1.Type of substance

  • example: iron rusts faster than steel.

2. Surface area

  • example: magnesium powder reacts faster than the same substance in big chunks.

3. Concentration

  • example: adding extra oxygen to a camp fire speeds up a burning camp fire.

4. Temperature

  • example: a camp fire burns increasily faster at a higher temperature.

5. Catalysts:

  • example: manganes(IV)oxide powder speeds up

the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, but doesn't take part in the reaction.

prompt.body:
An experienced camper knows that small twigs burn faster than a large pieces of wood.

Can you name the factor that the experienced camper used to speed up his camp fire?

content.body: concentration
type of substance
catalyst
temperature
surface area
Small twigs have a larger surface area and their particle size is smaller, so they burn faster.

prompt.body:
Bacteria and fungi decompose food quicker outside the fridge than inside the fridge.

Give an explanation for the difference in reaction [2p].

values.value:
It is colder in the fridge, so chemical reactions proceed slower. (This also means that bacterial activity is lower, so bacteria grow less quickly) [2p].

Or:

It is warmer outside the fridge, so chemical reactions proceed faster. (This also means that bacterial activity is higher, so bacteria grow more quickly) [2p].

content.body:
It is colder in the fridge, so chemical reactions proceed slower. (This also means that bacterial activity is lower, so bacteria grow less quickly) [2p].

Or:

It is warmer outside the fridge, so chemical reactions proceed faster. (This also means that bacterial activity is higher, so bacteria grow more quickly) [2p].

heading.content: Explain and Elaborate - Particle collision model

items.content:
Imagine the cars as analogies for molecules and atoms during a chemical reaction. According to the Particle collision model (also known as the Collision theory), a reaction takes place when the colliding cars (atoms, molecules) have enough energy.

Check out the Tedx analogy on the Collision model.

How could you increase the chance of having more collisions?

prompt.body:
Magnesium powder reacts faster with hydrochloric acid than magnesium ribbon.

Explain the difference in reaction rates with the particle collision model [2p].

values.value: The area of contact/surface area is much greater with magnesium powder than with magnesium ribbon [1p]; the chance that an acid particle collides with a magnesium particle is much greater [1p].

content.body: The area of contact/surface area is much greater with magnesium powder than with magnesium ribbon [1p]; the chance that an acid particle collides with a magnesium particle is much greater [1p].

prompt.body:
Magnesium reacts faster with hot hydrochloric acid than with cold hydrochloric acid.

Explain the difference in reaction rates using the particle collision model [2p].

values.value: In a hot solution the particles move faster and collide more energetically [1p]. The chance of an effective collision between acid and magnesium is therefore greater in hot hydrochloric acid [1p].

content.body: In a hot solution the particles move faster and collide more energetically [1p]. The chance of an effective collision between acid and magnesium is therefore greater in hot hydrochloric acid [1p].

prompt.body:
Magnesium reacts faster with concentrated hydrochloric acid than with dilute hydrochloric acid.

Explain the difference in reaction rates using the particle collision model [2p].

values.value: Concentrated hydrochloric acid contains more acid than dilute hydrochloric acid [1p]. The chance that acid collides with magnesium is therefore greater [1p].

content.body: Concentrated hydrochloric acid contains more acid than dilute hydrochloric acid [1p]. The chance that acid collides with magnesium is therefore greater [1p].

items.content: Complete the diagnostic test to track your own progress.

header.title: Diagnostic Test Ch3 paragraph 3.4 Rate of reaction

questions.label: Carbon dioxide gas as an extinguishing method

prompt.body: Use the particle collision model to explain how carbon dioxide gas extinguishes a fire [2p].

values.value: Carbon dioxide gas extinguishes a fire because the carbon dioxide molecules take the place of the oxygen molecules [1p]. Oxygen can no longer collide with the fuel [1p].

content.body: Carbon dioxide gas extinguishes a fire because the carbon dioxide molecules take the place of the oxygen molecules [1p]. Oxygen can no longer collide with the fuel [1p].

prompt.body:
Sawdust has a large surface area but it does not react with air.

Explain this using the particle collision model [2p].

values.value: Sawdust is a fine powder, but as this powder is in a heap, oxygen molecules can only collide with the outside layer of the heap [1p]. If the heap of sawdust is blown into the air and exposed to a flame this can cause an explosion! [1p]

content.body: Sawdust is a fine powder, but as this powder is in a heap, oxygen molecules can only collide with the outside layer of the heap [1p]. If the heap of sawdust is blown into the air and exposed to a flame this can cause an explosion! [1p]
